Abstract: The resurrection of the 1918 influenza virus through reverse genetics has provided unprecedented insights into the mechanisms of virulence and transmission that contributed to the deadliest pandemic in human history. By reconstructing the virus and studying its behavior in various models, researchers have identified key genetic determinants that enhance pathogenicity and facilitate efficient human-to-human spread. These findings have not only deepened our understanding of the 1918 pandemic but also informed the development of strategies to mitigate future influenza threats. The study of the resurrected virus has underscored the importance of surveillance, rapid response, and the development of universal vaccines. This research highlights the critical role of historical virus analysis in preparing for and potentially preventing future pandemics, offering valuable lessons in the ongoing battle against influenza and other emerging infectious diseases.
